title: Walter Wojdakowski
text:
Walter Wojdakowski (born March 29, 1950) is a retired <a href="United%20States%20Army">United States Army</a> <a href="Major%20General">Major General</a>. He held a number of high positions within the military, including his last post as Commanding General of <a href="Fort%20Benning">Fort Benning</a>.
Military career.
Education.
Wojdakowski graduated from the <a href="United%20States%20Military%20Academy">United States Military Academy</a> at <a href="West%20Point%2C%20New%20York">West Point</a> in 1972. He has a <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Science">Bachelor of Science</a> and a <a href="Master%20of%20Business%20Administration">Master of Business Administration</a> from the <a href="University%20of%20Alaska">University of Alaska</a> and a <a href="Master%20of%20Military%20Arts%20and%20Sciences">Master of Military Arts and Sciences</a> from the <a href="U.S.%20Army%20Command%20and%20General%20Staff%20College">U.S. Army Command and General Staff College</a>. He is a member of the <a href="Phi%20Kappa%20Phi">Phi Kappa Phi Honor Society</a>. His military education includes the Infantry Officer Basic and Advanced Courses, the Command and General Staff College, the School of Advanced Military Studies, and the <a href="United%20States%20Army%20War%20College">Army War College</a>.
Service.
Wojdakowski served in company grade officer positions as a Platoon Leader, Scout Platoon Leader, Executive Officer, Ranger Instructor and Commander at <a href="Fort%20Lewis%20%28Washington%29">Fort Lewis</a> and at the Army Mountain Ranger Camp. He also was an Assistant Professor of Military Science at the <a href="University%20of%20Alaska%20Fairbanks">University of Alaska Fairbanks</a>. As a field grade officer, he served as a Brigade <a href="Staff%20officer">S-3</a>, Battalion Executive Officer and Chief, Tactical Operations III Corps G-3 at <a href="Fort%20Hood">Fort Hood</a>, <a href="Texas">Texas</a>. He commanded the 3rd Battalion, <a href="41st%20Infantry%20Regiment%20%28United%20States%29">41st Infantry Regiment</a>, Tiger Brigade, <a href="2nd%20Armored%20Division%20%28United%20States%29">2nd Armored Division</a> at Fort Hood and in <a href="Desert%20Storm">Desert Storm</a>/<a href="Operation%20Desert%20Shield%20%28Gulf%20War%29">Desert Shield</a> from 1989 to 1991. He was then assigned as the Senior Infantry Task Force Combat Trainer at the <a href="National%20Training%20Center">National Training Center</a>, <a href="Fort%20Irwin">Fort Irwin</a>, <a href="California">California</a>. He attended the U.S. Army War College, <a href="Carlisle%20Barracks">Carlisle Barracks</a>, <a href="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a> and commanded the <a href="11th%20Infantry%20Regiment%20%28United%20States%29">11th Infantry Regiment</a> at Ft Benning, Georgia from July 1993 to July 1995. Wojdakowski's next assignment was as the Director of Training, 7th Army Training Command, <a href="USAREUR">USAREUR</a> and he became the Commander, Operations Group, Combat Maneuver Training Center at the <a href="Hohenfels%2C%20Bavaria">Hohenfels</a> <a href="http%3A//www.hohenfels.army.mil">Training Area</a>, <a href="Germany">Germany</a> on 1 May 1996. Wojdakowski assumed the duties of Assistant Commandant of the Infantry School and Deputy Commanding General, Fort Benning, on 21 January 1997. In September 1998 he became Chief, Office of Military Cooperation, <a href="Kuwait">Kuwait</a> at the U.S. Embassy in <a href="Kuwait%20City%2C%20Kuwait">Kuwait City, Kuwait</a>. He assumed duties as the ADC, <a href="24th%20Infantry%20Division%20%28United%20States%29">24th Infantry Division</a> (Mech) (Fwd) and Deputy Commanding General (DCG), <a href="1st%20U.S.%20Army">1st U.S. Army</a> on 17 August 2000. In September 2002 he assumed the position of DCG <a href="V%20Corps%20%28United%20States%29">V Corps</a>. He was later named DCG of the former <a href="Combined%20Joint%20Task%20Force%207">Combined Joint Task Force 7</a>, later succeeded by Multi-National Force-Iraq and <a href="Multi-National%20Corps-Iraq">Multi-National Corps-Iraq</a>. Wojdakowski here served as top deputy to Lt. Gen. <a href="Ricardo%20S.%20Sanchez">Ricardo S. Sanchez</a>, the force commander. After this post, he was eventually named Commanding General of Ft. Benning.
Abu Ghraib.
Along with other military and government personnel, Wojdakowski was investigated in the <a href="Abu%20Graib">Abu Graib</a> scandal.
<a href="Brigadier%20General%20%28United%20States%29">Brigadier General</a> <a href="Janis%20Karpinski">Janis Karpinski</a>, a general who was later disciplined for her role in the scandal, placed Maj. Gen. Wojdakowski at a meeting in late November at which there was extensive discussion of a <a href="International%20Red%20Cross">Red Cross</a> report that cited specific cases of abuse.
In November 2006, the <a href="Germany">German</a> government received a complaint seeking the prosecution of Wojdakowski for alleged war crimes. The complaint alleged that during his tenure he was legally responsible for the U.S. torture programs. After an investigation, he was cleared of all charges.
